Muller names Bayne-Jones chair
By LIZ WALLACE
President Muller has
announced the establishment of a
professorial chair at the Hopkins
Medical School made possible by
a grant from Mrs. Stanhope
Bayne-Jones.
The new chair will honor the
late Dr. Stanhope Bayne-Jones, a
distinguished bacteriologist who
served as Dean of the Yale
University Medical School and
Brigadier General of the United
States Army Medical Corps.
The committment comes in
response to the Hopkins
Hundreds Campaign to raise
$100 million for Hopkins
institutions, half of which will go
toward the establishment of 50
named professorial chairs.
Where's the $ Giong?
"I am enormously, pleased to
announce this pledge by Mrs.
Bayne -Jones for the
establishment of the Stanhope
Bayne-Jones Professorship in the

Johns Hopkins School of
Medicine," asserted Muller.
"Throughout his career. Dr.
Bayne-Jones exemplified the
highest standards of medicine
which an endowed chair in his
name will help greatly to
perpetuate."
Dr. Russell H. Morgan, Vice
President of the Hopkins Health
Divisions and Dean of the
Medical School, commented that
he was "delighted at the prospect
of an endowed professorship
honoring Stanhope Bayne-Jones,
a distinguished alumnus and
former faculty member at the
School of Medicine."
Bayne-Jones was one of 10
members of the United States
Surgeon General's Advisory
Commit tee on Smoking and
Health, which issued the 1964
report which linked smoking to
cancer. He received his B.A. from
Yale University in 1910 and his
M.D. from Hopkins in 1914.

Bayne-Jones was a member of
the Hopkins faculty for nine
years after which he taught at the
University of Rochester Medical
School. He became professor of
bacteriology at Yale in 1932 and
became the dean of the Yale
Medical School three years later.
Bayne-Jones served at various
times on many government and
medical advisory boards. He was
also one of the most decorated
officers in the United States
Army, holding the Distinguished
Service Medal, the Silver Star,
and the Order of the British
Empire.
Previous donors of professorial
chairs in response to the Hopkins
Hundreds campaign include the
D. Mead Johnson Foundation,
Alonzo Decker Jr., Dr. Richard
TeLinde, Edward Schaffer, the
Andrew W. Mellon Foundation,
the Brown Foundation, and the
Jacob and Hilda Blaustein
Foundation.

Rutgers almost caught the
Hopkins lacrosse napping in New
Brunswick, but the Blue Jays

Muller names Bayne-Jones chair
By LIZ WALLACE
President Muller has
announced the establishment of a
professorial chair at the Hopkins
Medical School made possible by
a grant from Mrs. Stanhope
Bayne-Jones.
The new chair will honor the
late Dr. Stanhope Bayne-Jones, a
distinguished bacteriologist who
served as Dean of the Yale
University Medical School and
Brigadier General of the United
States Army Medical Corps.
The committment comes in
response to the Hopkins
Hundreds Campaign to raise
$100 million for Hopkins
institutions, half of which will go
toward the establishment of 50
named professorial chairs.
Where's the $ Giong?
"I am enormously, pleased to
announce this pledge by Mrs.
Bayne -Jones for the
establishment of the Stanhope
Bayne-Jones Professorship in the

Johns Hopkins School of
Medicine," asserted Muller.
"Throughout his career. Dr.
Bayne-Jones exemplified the
highest standards of medicine
which an endowed chair in his
name will help greatly to
perpetuate."
Dr. Russell H. Morgan, Vice
President of the Hopkins Health
Divisions and Dean of the
Medical School, commented that
he was "delighted at the prospect
of an endowed professorship
honoring Stanhope Bayne-Jones,
a distinguished alumnus and
former faculty member at the
School of Medicine."
Bayne-Jones was one of 10
members of the United States
Surgeon General's Advisory
Commit tee on Smoking and
Health, which issued the 1964
report which linked smoking to
cancer. He received his B.A. from
Yale University in 1910 and his
M.D. from Hopkins in 1914.

Bayne-Jones was a member of
the Hopkins faculty for nine
years after which he taught at the
University of Rochester Medical
School. He became professor of
bacteriology at Yale in 1932 and
became the dean of the Yale
Medical School three years later.
Bayne-Jones served at various
times on many government and
medical advisory boards. He was
also one of the most decorated
officers in the United States
Army, holding the Distinguished
Service Medal, the Silver Star,
and the Order of the British
Empire.
Previous donors of professorial
chairs in response to the Hopkins
Hundreds campaign include the
D. Mead Johnson Foundation,
Alonzo Decker Jr., Dr. Richard
TeLinde, Edward Schaffer, the
Andrew W. Mellon Foundation,
the Brown Foundation, and the
Jacob and Hilda Blaustein
Foundation.
